text: So here you have Republicans and
Democrats coming together to get
something done, and they want to
make sure people know about it.
Now, whether these news stories can
break through the filter of our
social media and all the cat videos
we're watching, I'm not sure.
But I do think in terms of putting
that message forward, you're seeing
an affirmative that for both from
the administration and also
supporters on Capitol Hill.
I'm Ronnie Chatterjee.
I'm a professor of business and
public policy at Duke University.
I was formerly the chief economist
of the United States Department of
Commerce and the white House
coordinator for the Chips and
Science Act. I started in 2021
working for Secretary Raimondo at
the beginning of the administration.
This is the period where we had big
chip shortages all around the world,
and we were trying to figure out how
to make our supply chains more
resilient. The Chips act is part
of a broader set of policies, which
people often refer to as industrial
policy. What is industrial policy,
in short? It's when the government
provides support often subsidies,
grants, loans, tax credits
to key critical industries
to make sure they grow domestically.
Now, a lot of countries in Asia and
Europe have been doing this for a
long time, but really since the
1990s, these policies haven't been
in fashion in the United States.
And what's really interesting about
the Chips and Science Act and the
Inflation Reduction Act and the
bipartisan infrastructure law is
they constitute a return to
industrial policy.
There's a lot of potential, also a
lot of risks. And for business
leaders, they need to be thinking
about how these three sets of
policies are going to impact their
bottom lines and their employees.
How are you seeing businesses
respond to the legislation right
now.
When you're seeing massive amounts
of private sector investment on the
heels of these bills, the first
thing that I think business leaders
are noting is that they're making
bets on America again, because the
Biden administration has said, look,
we're going to build chips in the
United States again.
So since the Chips and Science Act
passed in 2022, we've seen
over $150 billion
in private sector investment in the
United States in semiconductors.
You're seeing that in the Inflation
Reduction Act as well.
A lot of the climate adjacent
industries think wind, solar,
carbon capture and storage, green
hydrogen, hundreds of billions of
dollars in investment has come from
the private sector since the
Inflation Reduction Act passed.
So I think the first thing you're
seeing from the private sector is a
lot of interest and a lot of
investment.
Are you seeing any impacts
that are surprising to you right
now?
What surprised me most is the
geographic footprint of the
investments we've seen so far.
Manufacturing investments in rural
areas make a lot of sense because
this is where we have a lot of
manufacturing already.
In the South, we've seen a lot of
manufacturing moving there over the
last 25 years.
Now we're hopeful to see investments
all across the country.
What advice do you have for business
leaders who are looking to take
advantage of this legislation?
First, you have to understand the
rules of the game.
Pieces of legislation are very
complicated, really making sure that
your government affairs team and the
C-suite is paying attention to how
those rules are being written and
how it affects your firm, is
incredibly important.
Second thing is keeping the
communication channels open.
A lot of times in government, we
need to hear from the private sector
about what frictions they have to
making more investment, for example,
to solve our climate challenges.
We need to go from the billions of
dollars in the Inflation Reduction
Act to trillions of dollars in
private sector investment.
That's only going to happen if we
unlock private sector capital.
We need to hear from business
leaders about what the frictions
are, to the point that.
So what headlines would you expect
to see in a couple of years
due to the legislation?
If we're successful, I think what
you'll see is leading edge capacity
on the chip side in the United
States for the first time in a long
time. Right now, the most leading
edge ships are made in East Asia.
92% of those are in Taiwan.
If we succeed over the next decade,
I think you'll see those plants
being built in the United States
starting to put out a large amount
of new advanced logic chips
in the United States.
I think that's key.
I think you'll also see a larger
share of the infrastructure for our
energy transition being made in the
United States, and hopefully you'll
see the companies that are producing
those things in good financial
situations.
If you see that, I think we'll be
successful. Those are the headlines
we're looking for.
